verses.text: And David numbered the people that \add were\add* with him, and set captains of thousands and captains of hundreds over them.

And David sent forth a third part of the people under the hand of Joab , and a third part under the hand of Abishai the son of Zeruiah , Joab’s brother , and a third part under the hand of Ittai the Gittite. And the king said unto the people , I will surely go forth with you myself also.

But the people answered , Thou shalt not go forth : for if we flee away , they will not care for us; neither if half of us die , will they care for us: but now \add thou art\add* worth ten thousand of us: therefore now \add it is\add* better that thou succour us out of the city.\f + \fr 18.3 \ft care…: Heb. set their heart on us\f*\f + \fr 18.3 \ft worth…: Heb. as ten thousand of us\f*\f + \fr 18.3 \ft succour: Heb. be to succour or help\f*
And the king said unto them, What seemeth you best I will do. And the king stood by the gate side , and all the people came out by hundreds and by thousands.

And the king commanded Joab and Abishai and Ittai , saying , \add Deal\add* gently for my sake with the young man , \add even\add* with Absalom. And all the people heard when the king gave all the captains charge concerning Absalom. \p
¶ So the people went out into the field against Israel : and the battle was in the wood of Ephraim ;
Where the people of Israel were slain before the servants of David , and there was there a great slaughter that day of twenty thousand \add men\add*.
For the battle was there scattered over the face of all the country : and the wood devoured more people that day than the sword devoured.\f + \fr 18.8 \ft devoured: Heb. multiplied to devour\f* \p

¶ And Absalom met the servants of David. And Absalom rode upon a mule , and the mule went under the thick boughs of a great oak , and his head caught hold of the oak , and he was taken up between the heaven and the earth ; and the mule that \add was\add* under him went away.
And a certain man saw \add it\add*, and told Joab , and said , Behold, I saw Absalom hanged in an oak.

And Joab said unto the man that told him, And, behold, thou sawest \add him\add*, and why didst thou not smite him there to the ground ? and I would have given thee ten \add shekels\add* of silver , and a girdle.

And the man said unto Joab , Though I should receive a thousand \add shekels\add* of silver in mine hand , \add yet\add* would I not put forth mine hand against the king’s son : for in our hearing the king charged thee and Abishai and Ittai , saying , Beware that none \add touch\add* the young man Absalom.\f + \fr 18.12 \ft receive: Heb. weigh upon mine hand\f*\f + \fr 18.12 \ft Beware…: Heb. Beware whosoever ye be of, etc\f*
Otherwise I should have wrought falsehood against mine own life : for there is no matter hid from the king , and thou thyself wouldest have set thyself against \add me\add*.

Then said Joab , I may not tarry thus with thee. And he took three darts in his hand , and thrust them through the heart of Absalom , while he \add was\add* yet alive in the midst of the oak.\f + \fr 18.14 \ft with…: Heb. before thee\f*\f + \fr 18.14 \ft midst: Heb. heart\f*
And ten young men that bare Joab’s armour compassed about and smote Absalom , and slew him.
And Joab blew the trumpet , and the people returned from pursuing after Israel : for Joab held back the people.
And they took Absalom , and cast him into a great pit in the wood , and laid a very great heap of stones upon him: and all Israel fled every one to his tent. \p

¶ Now Absalom in his lifetime had taken and reared up for himself a pillar , which \add is\add* in the king’s dale : for he said , I have no son to keep my name in remembrance : and he called the pillar after his own name : and it is called unto this day , Absalom’s place. \p

¶ Then said Ahimaaz the son of Zadok , Let me now run , and bear the king tidings , how that the \nd \+w LORD|strong="H3068"\+w*\nd* hath avenged him of his enemies.\f + \fr 18.19 \ft avenged…: Heb. judged him from the hand, etc\f*

And Joab said unto him, Thou shalt not bear tidings this day , but thou shalt bear tidings another day : but this day thou shalt bear no tidings , because the king’s son is dead.\f + \fr 18.20 \ft bear tidings this: Heb. be a man of tidings, etc\f*
Then said Joab to Cushi , Go tell the king what thou hast seen. And Cushi bowed himself unto Joab , and ran.

Then said Ahimaaz the son of Zadok yet again to Joab , But howsoever , let me, I pray thee, also run after Cushi. And Joab said , Wherefore wilt thou run , my son , seeing that thou hast no tidings ready ?\f + \fr 18.22 \ft howsoever: Heb. be what may\f*\f + \fr 18.22 \ft ready: or, convenient\f*
But howsoever, \add said he\add*, let me run. And he said unto him, Run. Then Ahimaaz ran by the way of the plain , and overran Cushi.
And David sat between the two gates : and the watchman went up to the roof over the gate unto the wall , and lifted up his eyes , and looked , and behold a man running alone.
And the watchman cried , and told the king. And the king said , If he \add be\add* alone, \add there is\add* tidings in his mouth. And he came apace , and drew near.
And the watchman saw another man running : and the watchman called unto the porter , and said , Behold \add another\add* man running alone. And the king said , He also bringeth tidings.

And the watchman said , Me thinketh the running of the foremost is like the running of Ahimaaz the son of Zadok. And the king said , He \add is\add* a good man , and cometh with good tidings.\f + \fr 18.27 \ft Me…: Heb. I see the running\f*

And Ahimaaz called , and said unto the king , All is well. And he fell down to the earth upon his face before the king , and said , Blessed \add be\add* the \nd \+w LORD|strong="H3068"\+w*\nd* thy God , which hath delivered up the men that lifted up their hand against my lord the king.\f + \fr 18.28 \ft All…: or, Peace be to thee: Heb. Peace\f*\f + \fr 18.28 \ft delivered…: Heb. shut up\f*

And the king said , Is the young man Absalom safe ? And Ahimaaz answered , When Joab sent the king’s servant , and \add me\add* thy servant , I saw a great tumult , but I knew not what \add it was\add*.\f + \fr 18.29 \ft Is…: Heb. Is there peace?\f*
And the king said \add unto him\add*, Turn aside , \add and\add* stand here. And he turned aside , and stood still.

And, behold, Cushi came ; and Cushi said , Tidings , my lord the king : for the \nd \+w LORD|strong="H3068"\+w*\nd* hath avenged thee this day of all them that rose up against thee.\f + \fr 18.31 \ft Tidings: Heb. Tidings is brought\f*

And the king said unto Cushi , Is the young man Absalom safe ? And Cushi answered , The enemies of my lord the king , and all that rise against thee to do \add thee\add* hurt , be as \add that\add* young man \add is\add*. \p

¶ And the king was much moved , and went up to the chamber over the gate , and wept : and as he went , thus he said , O my son Absalom , my son , my son Absalom ! would God I had died for thee , O Absalom , my son , my son !
